Import libraries

```{python}
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from scipy.optimize import curve_fit
```

# Day 1: Direct Current

## Polarization Calibration

Import our data

```{python}
no_rod = pd.read_csv("data/day1/no_rod.csv")
with_rod = pd.read_csv("data/day1/with_rod.csv")
```

Plot it around 0 (Wrapping between -180 and 180)

```{python}
x = [x if x < 180 else x-360 for x in list(no_rod["angle"])]
y = list(no_rod["voltage"])
x_rod = [x if x < 180 else x-360 for x in list(with_rod["angle"])]
y_rod = list(with_rod["voltage"])
plt.figure()
plt.scatter(x,y)
plt.scatter(x_rod,y_rod)
plt.plot()
```

fit the data over a cosine curve

```{python}
def cosine(x, a, b, c):
  return a*np.cos(b*x - c)
curve_fit(cosine,no_rod["angle"], no_rod["voltage"])

```

## DC Verlet

Import the data

```{python}
verlet1 = pd.read_csv("data/day1/dc_verdet_1.csv")
verlet2 = pd.read_csv("data/day1/dc_verdet_2.csv")
```

Plot the angle change vs intensity (read as current)

```{python}
plt.figure()
plt.scatter(verlet1["current"],verlet1["angle change"])
plt.scatter(verlet2["current"],verlet2["angle change"])
plt.show()
```

Here we are accurate to the about 2 degrees of precision, which is not a whole lot. This will be improved in the AC section.
